Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Context-Dependency in the Exploitation of Pollination Mutualisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Why cooperation between species is so common and how it can persist in the face of cheating is one of the great enigmas in biology. This project will explore how ecological conditions can cause a species to switch between benefiting and parasitizing another species, using one of the most important cases of cooperation, the pollination of plants by animals. This key type of mutually beneficial relationship between species can switch to a parasitic relationship when animal pollinators steal nectar from flowers without transferring pollen. The project will combine field observations, manipulative experiments, and a model of two bee species that switch between pollinating and cheating in the Rocky Mountains to determine (1) when and why bees cheat the plants they visit; (2) whether cheating or cooperation benefits the bees more under different circumstances; and (3) how nectar robbing affects the reproduction of the plants that the bees visit.

The broader impacts of this project include student training, outreach to the general public, and greater understanding of a major ecosystem service. The project will train undergraduate students, a graduate student, and a postdoctoral researcher. Public outreach is planned through museums, middle and high schools, and summer science camps. Results will increase understanding of pollination, a critical service for agriculture and conservation of biodiversity: identifying the conditions under which pollinators refrain from cheating could help increase crop yields and maintain native plant species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Why cooperation is so common and how it can persist in the face of cheating is one of the great enigmas in biology. It is one that is also very pertinent to understanding how humans can get along even when our interests fail to coincide. Our understanding how cooperation works in nature is surprisingly limited, however. The ecological conditions under which organisms will and will not choose to cooperate are barely known, nor are the costs of being duped by a cheater. Interactions between plants and nectar-feeding animals are ideal systems for studying these questions. Pollinators are cooperators of plants: they feed from flowers in a way that leads them to pick up and move pollen. In contrast, primary nectar robbers are cheaters that steal nectar through holes they bite in flowers, often without transferring pollen, and secondary nectar robbers steal additional nectar through those holes. Bees are especially interesting to study, because individuals exhibit two or even all three of these behaviors. Why do they sometimes cooperate with plants, and at other times cheat them?

 

Using three plant species and three bumblebee species, this project, carried out in alpine Colorado, has combined field observations and manipulative experiments to determine (1) when and why bees choose to cheat versus cooperate, and (2) the consequences of these choices for both partners. Experiments conducted by a large team of undergraduate and graduate students are showing that for each bee and plant species combination, one feeding tactic (pollination, primary or secondary robbing) is the most efficient: that is, it provides the most energy per unit time spent feeding. We have shown that this is indeed usually the feeding tactic seen for that bee species on that plant in nature. However, bees make many puzzling choices. These include, for example, individuals that persistently employ clearly inefficient feeding tactics. Our work is suggesting that bees prioritize familiarity with a given tactic, over whether it is the best one available.

 

The scientific literature on cooperation is based, we have argued, on some unwarranted assumptions, including that there is a so-called “temptation to cheat” that must be countered by the “duped” partner if cooperation is to persist in nature. Our work takes the rare perspective of the organism that faces the choice in question, whether or not to cooperate; it is demonstrating that there are many situations in which cooperation is the more logical choice, but also that, even when “crime pays”,  biological forces not previously acknowledged, such as cognitive constraints, may lead cooperation to persist. Two doctoral dissertations and two undergraduate honors theses were completed in the course of this project. We also used our study system to offer hands-on experience in the biology of cooperation to students and lifelong learners in Colorado, Arizona and North Carolina. Finally, we and the students we trained presented several public lectures on the fate of beneficial interactions in the face of global climate change.
